item.description:
This hike is new to us and thus experimental. This looks to be an interesting pair of preserves (520 acres total) with old mines (lead and silver, later iron), historic huge roasting ovens for the iron ore, quarries, and steep and varied terrain. This hike is about 5.5 miles in length and moderate in effort due to some steepness and length. Mine Hill is a National Historic Landmark.

We will start out from the parking area and check out the blast furnace and roasting ovens for the iron ore that was processed in this area around 1867. After exploring the historic site, We will follow the Main Loop on the Donkey Trail in the Mine Hill Preserve up to the mine entrances (mining stared around 1750) and take a peek as we find them. From there we continue up and and past the gated vent shafts of the mines and on to the quarries. From there we take a bridge to the Carter Trail to do a loop in the Carter Preserve which is only accessible via this route. After we loop back to the quarries, we continue on the Main Loop and eventually back to the parking area.

We will take up to 4.5 hrs. for this hike as we take deep appreciation for the views of the furnaces, mines, quarries, and of course nature!

Those who wish to go need to have:
* A daypack
* 1-2 quarts of water
* Trail food/lunch
* Hiking boots
* Dress in layers - So you can take off as you heat up, no cotton

Optional equipment:
* Bug spray
* Camera
* Hiking pole(s)
* Headlamp or flashlight - to peek in the entrances to the mines

The number of parking spaces is unknown.

Dogs are allowed but preferred leashed per the park rules. This hike may not be dog appropriate for all dogs due to steep sections and open mine shafts.
